utterances: There are.
All of them stressed the need to boost exports and promote free trade, although Republicans say Mr. Obama hasn't moved fast enough in that area.
And they all stressed the importance of a more educated workforce as the global economy gets more and more competitive.
Mr. Obama told students in Richmond today, I know you're having fun here at the university, but you've gotta hit the books.
Thanks, Scott.
My pleasure, Robert.
That's NPR's Scott Horsley speaking with us from the White House.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
Good morning, my beloved Venezuela.
Chavez had been in Cuba, where he had a cancerous tumor removed.
And he was widely expected to remain there for a long period of recuperation.
Then, unexpectedly, along with his tweet, came Chavez himself.
He arrived in Caracas before dawn today, just in time for a made-for-Chavez event: The bicentennial of Venezuela's independence on Tuesday.
NPR's Juan Forero joins us now from Caracas.
And, Juan, there'd been a lot of mystery involving the health of Hugo Chavez over the past month.
What happened?
Well, Chavez had basically disappeared for three weeks, only saying he'd undergone an emergency surgery in Cuba.
That really turned politics upside down in Venezuela because the president is always on TV.
He's either giving speeches, or presiding over summits, or hosting his television show.
He is omnipresent here in Venezuela and his government really revolves around him.
So his absence and the questions it raised caused quite a bit of anxiety.
And then he announced last week that the operation had removed a cancerous tumor.
It was stunning for people in Venezuela.
And does his return answer any other questions about his health and how long his recovery might take?
Well, surprisingly, not that much.
He spoke Thursday night in a short -I mean, it was just 13-minute address.
That's strange for a guy who can talk seven hours.
And he said the operation had been a success.
But he never said what kind of cancer.
He never said what kind of treatments he'd been receiving.
Government ministers tried to assure people that everything was normal, that Chavez remained in charge.
And over the weekend, state TV began showing documentaries about Chavez, commercials about Chavez, and issuing videos of Chavez in Cuba.
Here he is, quite alive and recuperating, and he's going to be home at some point in the future.
And then he came home.
He's there now.
Why so soon?
Well, I think that this is a way for the government to show that Chavez is getting better and getting better fast.
Remember that Chavez has a mystical connection with his people.
He's held up by some here as a messiah who's delivered them from the clutches of the oligarchs and the gringos - meaning the United States.
There's a potential for McLellan and others to collect much more.
It's estimated that just 10 percent of hospitals around the country have arrangements to donate unused supplies.
When people see the process at night on network news, they see the refined product, the final product.
And I think they're kind of tired of that.
The want to see the real thing, and this is the real thing.
Facebook says 2.6 million people watch Ramos's videos on the night of the Iowa caucuses.
His videos on New Hampshire's primary day drew more than 4 million viewers.
Those figures rival or exceed cable news audiences.
Look; I've been doing this for 30 years, and suddenly, I'm - I just have here a cell phone and broadcasting everything on a cell phone.
He said they're going where the audience is.
I called over Dax Tejera.
He's the executive producer of ""AMERICA With Jorge Ramos,"" which runs on Fusion.
Dax - you join us for a sec?
Whose idea was this particular project?
It was our idea.
It was your idea.
You told me - you went to my office and said, we have to report, but let's do it only on Facebook.
Yeah, and look.

What we've known all the time for Fusion is that if we try to compete with CNN or Fox and do their ideas for our audience, it won't work because that model has been tried, tested, and they've perfected it.

So we constantly think about who our audience is and where they are, and it was increasingly clear to us that people were coming to see us through Facebook and that when Facebook Live became an option, it was a no-brainer, I think.
During the live streams, Ramos often toggles back and forth between Spanish and English.
The question of language and identity surfaced as Ramos talked with Mike Malzone, a local contractor and Merrimack Tea Party activist.
He had been standing in the cold for hours, holding a poster for Trump.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
He brought heaters and coffee for everyone, and we don't really - we gave something to everyone that was here because we're not haters.
We respect the process.
It's interesting that you say, we're not haters because some people might think that Mexicans, Muslims, women might not be welcome.
Oh, disagree.
Then Malzone turned the question back on Ramos and Univision.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I was disappointed with your station for quite some time because I could never SAP your station in English, and it's only been...
Now you can do it, right?
Yeah, but it's only been the last couple years.
Exactly.
SAP - that's the way to receive translation of Univision's Spanish newscasts into English in real time.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
That's not right.
I couldn't SAP that in English.
That wasn't cool, Man, right?
But is that racism?
No, it's not racism.
We simply broadcast in Spanish.
That's all.
Yeah, but...
But now I'm almost - also working for Fusion, so you can watch whatever we do in both English and...
It's about time.
Thank God.
Ramos later told me he valued the contentious exchange with Malzone.
I don't have the prompter or the lights or the set.
It's the nature of our business - is true reporting and seeing.
It was all right there for anyone to see.
David Folkenflik, NPR News.
In Texas, voters will decide their top picks for governor in next week's primary.
State Senator Wendy Davis is the Democratic hopeful.
She's challenging Republican Greg Abbott, who is the state's attorney general.
Both are expected to easily win their primaries, but neither candidate has gotten off to a particularly strong start.
NPR's Wade Goodwyn joined us from Dallas to talk about the race.
